title: What is the most efficient way to learn a piano piece? - Quora

response.answer_text: What is the most efficient way to learn a piano piece Useful Carl Ware 's methods and ways to l_e_a_r_n pianno effectivly in 6 weeks.Thank Carl Ware 5 WAYS TO LEARN PIANO EFFECTIVELY IN 6 WEEKS: 1. Get your friend or relative or acquaintance to teach you piano. This is perhaps the cheapest and easiest method. You can learn fast because it is after all your friend or relative who is teaching you, and you can fix the time as per your requirements. Of course you will need the piano, and some resources, but if you are not planning to learn it to become a pro, then you can perhaps do away with the resource materials. You can also be quite sure of learning some good simple songs quite early and can show them off to your friends too! 2. Find some good online resources where everything related to piano is being taught. Find a website where there are lots of video lessons, ample resources and tips as well as some kind of a schedule-based learning curriculum. Stick to the site (which means do not keep switching sites and dropping them) and learn everything that it teaches. There are plenty of them today which have a very thorough and clear resources including lessons, exercises etc. Below are suggested resources to learn piano by Quorarian Jennife Lee: . Private teachers . Piano schools . Best 3 piano channels on YouTube: LearnPianoLive, HDpiano, PianoPig. . Best forums: Reddit piano (125k members) is the best place to discuss and learn piano. Alteratives: Pianostreet forum, Pianoworld forum . PianoHandbook365 .club/2019/free-ebook-31-tips-to-become-a-pro-piano-player.html . Best frree training site: 701PianoVideos .info 3. Get a piano learning software program. They might cost you a bit, but when they come with plenty of video lessons and resource manuals, as wells as thousands of lessons, exercises and even evaluating tools, you can almost think of it as a piano tutor! 4. Learning from a tutor. The first thing that may come into your mind if you are thinking of learning the piano is to find a personal tutor who can help you learn the instrument. This can mean allotting your time to a fixed schedule every week to be able to go to your personal tutor or have him come over for the tutorial. One advantage of course of a personal tutor is the fact that he can see you learn and correct you as soon as he finds you not doing it correctly. 5. Learning on your own. Yes, you can actually learn to play piano on your own. With a lot of resources you can find around you, learning the piano can be easy. You can find free tutorial videos online, or find websites and blogs of music enthusiasts who are generous enough to share their skills. However, it is important to keep in mind that learning on your own especially if you are a total beginner may not be the best way to learn piano. In learning the piano and any musical instruments, it is important that you have to learn it correctly right from the start and this may be a little difficult if you are on your own. In fact, one thing that can also be difficult with learning on your own is that, you may not be following the lessons step by step and errors that you may develop early on may not be corrected right away.

Okay, so I have a technique that may or may not work, depending on the pianist. But, I did learn Liszt’s Second Hungarian Rhapsody(famous piece) in three weeks at the tender age of sixteen using this technique, so there’s that(and I learned the notes, mind you. Interpretation of that piece is a wild entity in and of itself). Step One: Sit down, and spread out the sheet music. Note patterns, or where certain sections repeat. If it’s a sonata or sonatina of some sort, there DEFINITELY is some repetition, so keep looking. Step Two: I’m going to be burned alive for this, but take a pair of scissors to the sheet music, and cut it into sections by technique, or motif. Then, group them together, those that share the same technique, or motif. Label them however you wish(just make sure it’s organised somehow) Step Three: Learn the groups that you made separately. Make a practice schedule: practice all the sections labeled “A” for a day, then sections labeled “B” the next, etc etc. The reason for this is that it lets your brain and hands focus on one technique at a time. Some pieces are extremely frustrating, because they combine many techniques at once, and it becomes overwhelming almost at once. I had to learn the Torrent etude measure by measure(pretty much) because of how quickly it changes. An extreme example, but you get the point. Step Four: Go back to your original score(please get the torn-up sheet music online, don’t ruin a book…IMSLP is great for this), and begin to put the sections back together! You’re well on your way to learning a difficult piece! This works best for large rep, such as a Liszt Rhapsody, or a Chopin Ballade, or some such, Dense rep such as a Chopin etude won’t really work here. Hope this helps! If you want to comment what piece specifically you want help on, I could edit this reply… -hicco
